title: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie, review: Jesse Pinkman returns in a bloody, Easter egg-stuffed episode that we didn't really need
text:
No other television show has stuck its landing as emphatically and explosively as Breaking Bad did in 2013. Prestige TV’s crowning moment flamed out in a Götterdämmerung of machine-gun fire, soft rock and deftly ambiguous storytelling. The ambivalence centred chiefly on Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), last seen fleeing the scene of collaborator-turned-nemesis Walter White’s bloody downfall. We never knew what happened next to Jesse and, really, didn’t need to. He drove, sobbing and bloody, into the night. It was perfect.

The one person to quibble with this conclusion was the person who wrote it, Breaking Bad creator Vince Gilligan. Six years later he’s pulled a George Lucas and is now shedding further...
description: No other television show has stuck its landing as emphatically and explosively as Breaking Bad did in 2013.
